title: ap.analysis of pdes - Boundary regularity of the solution of a Poisson equation in a polyhedron
body: Let $d\in\mathbb N$ $\Lambda\subseteq\mathbb R^d$ be bounded and open $f\in L^2(\Lambda,\mathbb R^d)$ $u\in H_0^1(\Lambda,\mathbb R^d)$ with $$-\langle\nabla\phi,\nabla u\rangle_{L^2(\Lambda,\:\mathbb R^d)}=\langle\phi,f\rangle_{L^2(\Lambda)}\;\;\;\text{for all }\phi\in C_c^\infty(\Lambda)\tag1$$ It's well-known (see, for example, [1]) that if $\partial\Lambda\in C^2$ , then $u\in H^2(\Lambda)$ . Moreover (see [2]), if $d=2$ and $\partial\Lambda$ is "polygonal", we obtain $u\in H^2(\Lambda)$ as well. Now I'm interested in the case where $\Lambda$ is (bounded, open and) connected and $\partial\Lambda$ is Lipschitz. It's fine for me, if we additionally assume that $d\le 3$ . However, I doubt that these assumptions suffice to conclude. So, if that's indeed the case, is there any chance to show $u\in H^2(\Lambda)$ , if we assume that $\Lambda$ is a polyhedron ? [1]: Lawrence C. Evans, Partial Differential Equations , Theorem 6.3.4 [2]: Pierre Grisvard, Elliptic Problems in Nonsmooth Domains , Theorem 4.3.1.4 ap.analysis-of-pdes elliptic-pde laplacian polyhedra regularity Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 15, 2020 at 7:27 Community Bot 1 2 2 silver badges 3 3 bronze badges asked Feb 2, 2017 at 13:56 0xbadf00d 249 1 1 gold badge 6 6 silver badges 17 17 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 6 1 $\begingroup$ You quote Grisvard, but seem to overlook that his Theorem 3.2.1.2 does not need $d=2$, only convexity of the domain. $\endgroup$ Delio Mugnolo –  Delio Mugnolo 2017-02-02 15:02:05 +00:00 Commented Feb 2, 2017 at 15:02 $\begingroup$ @DelioMugnolo Indeeed, I didn't noticed that theorem. I didn't read the chapter yet. Is the theorem applicable for $Au:=\Delta u$, $u\in\mathcal D(A):=\left\{u\in H_0^1(\Lambda):u\text{ admits a weak Laplacian }\Delta u\in L^2(\Lambda)\right\}$, and $\Lambda$ being just bounded, convex and open (without any assumption on the boundary)? $\endgroup$ 0xbadf00d –  0xbadf00d 2017-02-03 15:58:37 +00:00 Commented Feb 3, 2017 at 15:58 $\begingroup$ use seperation of variables on a cone in $R^2$ with opening $ \alpha>0$ to look for harmonic functions in the cone which have zero Dirichlet BC. Probably when $ \pi< \alpha < 2 \pi$ i would assume the resulting solution is not in $H^2$ in any neighborhood of the vertex. $\endgroup$ Math604 –  Math604 2017-02-04 06:17:00 +00:00 Commented Feb 4, 2017 at 6:17 1 $\begingroup$ @0xbadf00d take a look at the book: condition (3,1,3,1) states that $A$ has to be uniformly elliptic, so yes, $\Delta$ will do. And no, there are no further assumptions on $\partial \Omega$. However, it is known that convexity is essential, even in dimension $d=2$, so I would guess tip on failure of boundary regularity for equations on non-convex polyhedra. $\endgroup$ Delio Mugnolo –  Delio Mugnolo 2017-02-04 20:30:32 +00:00 Commented Feb 4, 2017 at 20:30 $\begingroup$ @DelioMugnolo Do you know if the same can be shown in the case $d=3$ for the Stokes problem? I know that it's true for $d=2$ . I've asked for that in a separate question . $\endgroup$ 0xbadf00d –  0xbadf00d 2017-03-06 16:50:38 +00:00 Commented Mar 6, 2017 at 16:50  |  Show 1 more comment 0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
